headline.main: RESEARCH CASTS DOUBT ON LARGER CANCER RISK FOR WIVES OF SMOKERS

docs.lead_paragraph: A new American Cancer Society study, prepared by Lawrence Garfinkel, the association's vice president for epidemiology and statistics, has found no evidence that nonsmoking women whose husbands smoke are at greater risk of contracting lung cancer than women whose husbands do not smoke. The results of the study are to be published Tuesday in the June issue of the Journal of the National Cancer Institute. They run counter to the conclusions of a study released in January by a Japanese researcher, Dr. Takeshi Hirayama, who claimed to have found that nonsmoking wives whose husbands smoked developed lung cancer at a much greater rate than those with nonsmoking husbands.
